Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of High Precision Laser-based CO2 Isotope Analysis System for Atmospheric and Seawater Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Knowing the stable isotopic composition of a globally important atmospheric gas such as CO2 serves to provide useful 'fingerprint' information as to its source, and subsequent transformation.

Recent progress in measuring CO2 isotopes has concentrated on using quantum-cascade lasers (QCLS) together with multi-pass optical absorption cells. Such approaches have reached a point where QCLS multi-pass systems are now starting to match or better the capabilities of traditional magnetic sector mass spectrometers. They exhibit comparable precisions approaching 0.01 per mil in del 13C and del 18O, and with considerable advantages over the traditional systems in terms of reliability, analytical cost, and ease of sample preparation. These capabilities may have additional, yet to be developed applications. The instrumentation to be acquired here will use a high precision QCLS system for routine analysis of isotopic composition of CO2 in discrete air and seawater samples, opening the door for broader application of the technology to key environmental applications.

Institution.Name: University of California-San Diego Scripps Inst of Oceanography

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project supported the acquisition of components to develop a state-of-the- art analyzer system for measuring the isotopes of atmospheric CO2 and the isotopes of dissolved carbon in seawater. These components included a laser-isotope analyzer and they included additional components needed to build up inlet interfaces for introducing atmospheric and seawater samples.  The project supported the acquisition, but not the full development, assembly, and testing of the interfaces. Once operational, the instrument will enable a major equipment upgrade at Scripps. The equipment is expected to become the main method for measuring isotopes of atmospheric CO2 for the Scripps CO2 project, which continues the longest records of atmospheric CO2 isotopes, begun by Charles Keeling and continued under the PI. The instrument also will provide capability for high-precision measurement of carbon isotopes in seawater, which is of interest to several research groups at Scripps.  These applications require isotopic measurements of very high precision, which previously was possible only using a class of instrumentation called "magnetic sector mass spectrometers".  The newly acquired analyzer is among the first laser instruments to achieve precision comparable to the magnetic sector methods, but has major advantages by simplifying the time for sample preparation and allowing higher throughput rate of samples.
